title: John Oliver explains why Trump is a ‘pathological liar’ with ‘a well-documented 40-year history of bulls–t’ | National Post
text:
John Oliver explains why Trump is a ‘pathological liar’ with ‘a well-documented 40-year history of bulls–t’ Sadaf Ahsan | February 13, 2017 3:58 PM ET FarkIt 
John Oliver made his long-awaited return to TV on Sunday night with the season four premiere of Last Week Tonight, explaining all the ways President Donald Trump has proved himself to be a “pathological liar” with “a well-documented 40-year history of bullshit,” from his beliefs on voter fraud to the crime rate. 
“Since taking office around 412 years ago, Trump has made it clear that reality is not important to him,” he said. “Trump’s relationship with the truth is going to be of profound importance going forward because any policy discussion has to begin with a shared sense of reality and Trump’s reality can change within a single sentence.” 
Referencing the time when Trump claimed his inauguration had been rain-free, then cutting to video of this not being true, Oliver said, “We have a president capable of standing in the rain and saying it was a sunny day.” 
Oliver went on to talk about the media’s reaction to Trump’s election campaign and his policy platform. “It was worth taking him seriously,” he said. “Trump was telling the truth about the solutions to the problems he was lying about and he is now making real policy based on fake facts.” 
But if Trump sounds familiar at all, Oliver said, it’s because he seems to be listening to Fox News more than his team. “You would hope that as president, he would now be getting information from primary sources and briefings but Trump still watches a phenomenal amount of cable news,” he said. “His tweets frequently echo things that just aired on TV.” 
However, Trump’s favourite outlet seems to be none other than far-right website Breitbart, formerly managed by chief strategist Steve Bannon, which Oliver said contains “the kind of headlines you see your old high school friend share on Facebook and think, ‘Oh that’s a shame, I guess Greg sucks now.'” 
He continued, “There is a pattern here: Trump sees something that jibes with his worldview, doesn’t check it, half-remembers it and then passes it on, at which point it takes on a life of its own and appears to validate itself.” 
The problem being that “if you get your news from similar sources to him, as many, many, many people do, he doesn’t look like a crank, he looks like the first president to ever tell you the real truth.” 
And when confronted with Trump’s lies, adding insult to injury, White House press secretary Sean Spicer has a tendency to say it doesn’t matter if they’re true, because Trump believes them. 
“This isn’t about belief,” Oliver said. “It can’t be. Incidence of voter fraud is a verifiable fact and faith and facts aren’t like Bill Pullman and Bill Paxton. When you confuse them, it actually matters. Real people get hurt when you make policy based on false information. Billions will get spent on a wall that won’t work to prevent a crimewave that isn’t happening while refugees sit in dangerous situations to prevent Bowling Green-style massacres that never took place.” Related Samantha Bee praises CNN for feeding ‘flaxen-haired fountain of lies’ Kellyanne Conway to Jake Tapper 
Oliver’s solution? Since Trump likes cable news so much, he’ll begin buying ads for the Washington, D.C. area on major news outlets, like MSNBC, CNN and Fox News, in hopes that the president will catch a few and learn something, like climate change, how to use appetizer forks and what his other daughter’s name is. “Until we’re shut down,” Oliver said, “we are prepared to educate Donald Trump one by one on topics we’re pretty sure he doesn’t know about.”
